titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: I take up the story of my life from the point at which the record was broken off on Sunday afternoon May 9

. In the course of the afternoon I found myself feeling extremely ill. Nevertheless, I determined to make an effort to carry out my promise to preach at All Saints, Monkwearmouth. Accompanied by Lionel, I left the Castle shortly after 5 p.m., & motored to the Church.

I was in much pain, which the motion of the car did nothing to relieve. However, I robed, & sat in the Sanctuary while the service proceeded. But my pain increased, and when it was time for me to preach, I was quite unable to do more than crawl out of the Church on Lionel's arm. I got into the Car, & was carried back to the Castle in agony. There I went at once to bed, & sent for M
Cullagh. He gave me some remedies, & bade me remain in bed on Monday. Then, however, my state was worse: he suspected appendicitis, & asked to be allowed to send for M
Turner, the Newcastle specialist. Happily Turner was accessible, & came over at once. He confirmed the diagnosis, & ordered an operation
He insisted on immediate action. So, accompanied by M
time in succession I traversed the 25 miles between Bishop Auckland & Newcastle. It was truly a

. Groups of strikers were about the roads, & as we passed through Birtley we were stoned. At last we reached our journey's end, & I was received into the Nursing Home, where on Tuesday morning I underwent the operation, which (as the appendix was "virulent" and "gangrenous") probably saved my life
